intro: Chloraea ulanthoides var. grandis, commonly known as the large-flowered chloraea, is a striking member of the Rubiaceae family native to New Zealand. It is characterized by its large, showy white to pale blue flowers that are often tinged with pink, and it produces small, red berries that are edible for birds. The plant typically grows in coastal shrublands and is adapted to sandy, well-drained soils. It has lance-shaped leaves with a hairy underside and is known for its fragrant blooms. Due to its ornamental value and ecological importance, it is sometimes cultivated in gardens in New Zealand.
